author: @TheUrgeToLeaveAComment
text: I don‚Äôt think that their relationship being ‚Äútransactional‚Äù excuses Ice Spice‚Äôs treatment of Cleo. We‚Äôre so used to Capitalism dehumanizing those involved that decency and dignity can be treated as a luxury if we label an arrangement with capitalist terms. Their ‚Äútransaction‚Äù was still an interaction between two ppl, and when interacting with another person it is not right to be degrading towards them. So Ice Spice was wrong to be a terrible host. She was wrong to be a nasty person. Cleo was right to be upset that she was mistreated by the host with whom she made an arrangement with.

author: @ImanStevenson
text:
Certainly Cleo benefited from their relationship but there was also a clear power differential between the two particularly within the context of the tour. Because Ice was the headliner and everyone was there working for her, she could be particularly nasty to Cleo.

It‚Äôs also worth noting that there probably was a lot of ignorance on Cleo‚Äôs part. Ice Spice offered for her to join a tour that had budgets locked in long before she extended that invite, so Cleo shouldn‚Äôt even have accepted without both of their managers having a conversation to iron out details and understand expectations.

Cleo probably thought it‚Äôs last minute but theyve had a solid relationship thus far so when Ice says ‚ÄúI got you,‚Äù she assumed Ice‚Äôs perks and comforts would extend to her. Cleo, in my view, assumed the best of Ice and was unfortunately given a dose of reality.

replies.author: @aarongrays4471
replies.text: It‚Äôs good to see someone with a nuanced and realistic view on the subject. As someone that works in the industry ppl don‚Äôt even know that IceSpice went on the tour broke too. It‚Äôs not as simple as what ppl make it out to be.

replies.author: @katgreer6113
replies.text: yup. I would make sure all the perks and privileges extend to me first before going. then again cleo is a very small artist and probably jumped at the opportunity to promote herself.

replies.author: @reet7060
replies.text: @katgreer6113Well also it‚Äôs supposed to be a friend not a random stranger. She‚Äôs looked out for Ice in the past and assumed she was finally being rewarded for thatüòÇ

replies.author: @katgreer6113
replies.text:
@reet7060 
true but even with my BEST friend, i still ask what she means when she says she's gonna "treat me" tonight or whatever. I always wanna know who's paying for what, who's driving, etc...

Like...these kinds of things ruin friendships. Like we've just seen here. They are out here talking about chicken salads and watching someone's purses. 

It seems like Cleo DID ask for her stuff to be watched, so in that case, she was blindsided and ICE was the big bully about it. 

But as general life advice, always ask a friend the game plan, who's paying for dinner, how ya'll should split the bill, who's getting the uber/lyft...

People keep whole ass malice with each other because of things like this.
Nah. 
Also some people are funny. Even if you've treated them like angels before, never assume they'll treat you right until you SEE them doing so with ur own eyes. 

If I'm right, ICE was Cleo's former bully? Hell no. Looks like nothing really changed on the inside.

replies.author: @nbucwa6621
replies.text: If we are going to note the ignorance of Cleo for accepting then I think we should also note the ignorance/maliciousness of Ice Spice for offering when she should have known that budgets are locked in and she should have consulted with her manager and crew before telling Cleo that she wouldn't have to pay for or worry about anything during the tour. I also think Ice Spice has too much ego because she should have gone to Cleo immediately once her crew/manager started complaining about having to serve/budget an extra person and told her "I effed up. My manager doesn't wanna pay and there's all these issues. Can we figure out how to make you comfortable within these parameters or if you need to drop out then I understand". Instead she let Cleo suffer and blamed her at every turn.

author: @breannajenkins3526
text: i love this discussion but i do wish the issues of fatphobic were less breezed by and over taken the conversation of online cruelty bc that‚Äôs also something she perpetuates

author: @Dex-1723
text:
I think in this last stretch y'all are missing the fact that Cleo knew she wasn't going to get paid. She said she was going for exposure but she said Ice told her she was going to be part of the budget and she wouldn't have to pay for anything. That's the only reason she went because she wouldn't have to pay out of pocket and get things together in one day. She went on tour and in the middle they told her she wasn't part of the budget leaving her stranded. She didn't expect to be paid but she expected to have housing, food, etc because that's what she was told. For continuing the tour, she said she had invited her fans and Ice convinced her to not quit for her fans. Both Cleo and Ice identified each other as friends. Cleo gave Ice her clothes and I don't think on it's face Cleo 100 percent knew that she was being used for her blackness. She knew she was being used for her the cuteness of their closeness but not her blackness. 

You guys saying she isn't a victim is doing the "perfect victim" thing in my opinion. Because she "knew what would happen" and "well I wouldn't have if someone did this" type of thing is something people always say when it comes to victims. "Well they knew this was going to happen da da da" so that part didn't sit right with me.

replies.author: @Dex-1723
replies.text: As for exposure, she did get it I'm sure but Ice made her go on a whole hour before the show and she said there wast a lot of people there so again to kind of bully her. So I think in terms of that it wasn't much. Another thing about her exposing her I think is the fact that a lot of the things that happened were down right seem illegal but I guess technically isn't like her starving her or  leaving her bag outside and having her card get ran up with 700 dollars gone (which we don't know who did it but...). So I think it if it were na argument like Cleo said they got into about the jealousy thing and resolved it. She didn't take it to the internet but I think those things are like criminally evil for sure and within reason. That's not a slight difference in an argument between friends. That's some whole other ish in my opinion.

replies.author: @zoraanell
replies.text: @Dex-1723 I completely agree with this. It‚Äôs like signing up for an unpaid summer internship to gain experience and you end up doing coffee runs the whole time. You may have been able to network a teensy and look around the office but you were not able to practice/perfect your craft w/ hands-on experience. Ice Spice didn‚Äôt hold up her end of the deal.

replies.author: @judysm95
replies.text: @zoraanell I'd argue it's like signing up for a summer internship to gain experience and being pretty badly exploited, bullied, not given your breaks, ostracized, etc. Like it goes beyond I didn't get what I signed up for to fully I got treated horribly!

author: @SpiritVines
text: The term you‚Äôre all looking for is groupthink. We go on social media and instead of using critical thought we only see ppl as objects we can project onto, so if enough people hate someone we‚Äôll agree blindly or engage, or not share a different opinion out of fear of being ostracized. These conversations are important. No one is all good or all bad everyone does wrong so yeah agree. And yeah Ice should be held accountable. Truly.

author: @nick_stefanie
text: 57:47 this part when Rebecca talked about colorism and romantic experience growing up made me reflect a bit about my situation. Having a black family in my dad side and a white family in my mom side; a lightskin dad with a serious antiblackness problem; being racially ambiguous and being in majorly unambiguously white spaces where I was looked down upon and had comments about my features (hair, nose): I always found more comfort and acceptance in black people. Not only among my dad family (even though my dad actively tried to prevent it), but my best friends have mostly been black women, so it's not a surprise that my romantic interests since I was a pre-teenager have been black men. Mind you, I'm brazilian, so the racial experience of my people vary way more from the denial of being white than the claim to blackness ( due mainly to the myth of racial democracy in case someone is curious about it ), but I digress. It makes total sense to me when Rebecca talks about being romantically attracted in relation to perceiving your reality in an attempt to love yourself or at least accept yourself. That being said, another portion of my experience where maybe other people can relate but I don't see talked about often is the confrotation of race to racially ambiguous people ( including lightskin black people, from what I've been told ). In my house, race was never a conversation, probably due to my dad's self hatred and my mom's lack of racial consciousness. I just started thinking about it in university, when I was 18 years old, when people started assuming I was parda (light-skinned in Brasil) and I started making sense of some of my experience. But this where the catch is about the tragic mulatto BS and colorism,  that  were never a thing to me: if I took 18 years to be confronted about race, meaning my experiences "passed" in a way I didn't confront it myself, it is literally obvious that I benefit from my light skin. It's nothing to accept or disagree about, it's an objective fact. Dark-skinned people don't have that priviledge, period! I've seen my besties in multiple situations of racism that I never was and now I see my husband as well. It just baffles me that some people seek validation about themselves on behalf of something so gut-wrenching like racism. That's also where I fail to give grace to arguments such as "oh they were raised by this white parents that's why they feel left out",  dude I was raised by an antiblack light-skinned man and a very white woman. Understanding privileges is not that difficult when you don't place yourself in the center of the universe. All it takes is to sit down and LISTEN to a dark-skin person about their issues with colorism. It's not about you!!!

author: @Viyooml√≠ne
text: 34:17 CLOCK IT! Nicki big colorist and just like Drake she take on other identities one minute she Jamaican next she Chinese she British but was born in Trinidad üòÇ

author: @abookishmess
text:
I will say this 1:04:14  to this part of this conversation. If there's this glass ceiling for dark skin girls, especially in hip-hop i think there's a power imbalance, she was expecting exposure and opportunities for her likeness. She was minimized and harmed in hopes of furthering her career. Ice knew this position and privilege - she didn't expect backlash because society doesnt defend black women especially dark skinned black women. There's no perfect victims BUT i think Cleo is a victim.

Like she kept minimizing, humiliating, and demeaning this woman every chance in public. I don't get how we're framing the conversation with Ice Spice feelings as the center. Yes she's a human, and she invited her to the tour. I still think professionally she owed that girl better treatment and as a fellow black woman should have been kinder. Transaction or not doesn't give you the right to treat people anyway you want to and they just have to take it. Cleo put up with a lot of micro aggressions that were unacceptable. Cleo asked Ice about the finances and ICE SAID SHE GOT HER. 

I don't want to extend a courtesy to someone who took pleasure in perpetuating the pain she got onto others.

replies.author: @bruhofsteel
replies.text:
Yeah the centering of Ice Spice's feelings was very odd to me because at the end of the day, she took advantage of and mistreated Cleo. Being in the public eye does mean people will act like assholes to you and not treat you with any respect or care when they dislike you. This is true. However, I don't know if *this* was the right time or conversation to get into that. At times, it came across as minimizing the harm that had been done to Cleo, even though I know that was not the intent. 

On the transactional thing, i totally agree. I mean, my boss and I have a transactional relationship. Does that mean she gets to deny me a lunch break or spit in my face? I have a transactional relationship with a waiter, yet no one would tell them to chin up if I called them a name. Even transactional relationships should have a basic level of respect, decency, and professionalism between both parties.

author: @Oyinb358

I‚Äôm so happy Rebecca was on this panel, and was able to talk about her experience growing up as a dark skin little girl. Dark skin women and people repeatedly discuss the cruelty they experienced in childhood. I know Rebecca was an adorable little girl, and she deserved kindness.

Also Rebecca held Ice‚Äôs feet to the fire, if we realized that colorism is an extension of racism - we realize there‚Äôs no need to humanize colorists.

author: @harpbeat500
text: I disagree kinda with Herby Revolus take that the music industry is a cutthroat industry. I feel that hip hop especially certain segments of hip hop are cutthroat, dog eat dog world, but from the musicians that i know in rock/jazz, this drama would have not gone down like this. I think there is something to say that hip hop cultivates this type of competition in the music, especially at the higher levels of fame. I am not going to say that I don't have a list of favorite diss tracks, but there is not much of a we-in-this-together type of vibe in the hip hop game, unless its performative. That's really sad.

author: @twistysunshine
text:
My real issue with the "not nice" critique is like. When are men ever held to that standard. No one looks at like any single male rapper and goes "well hes mean". Not that they shouldnt! We probably should point out whos mean and who isnt. But i only ever see this directed at women as a thing. And this happens cross racially (altho black women and darker skinned women get MORE heat for being perceived as mean)- like i saw people poining out like Blake Lively as being mean during an interview like it was her greatest goddamn crime and i can think of several white men who are mean in interviews and everyone fuckin laughs and calls them cool. 

Like. Ice Spice obvs has some colorism and fatphobia that make her fucked up. Nicki Minaj has. So many internalized sexism issues. But people have this tendency to get drawn to their meanness and spend so much time critiquing that. Meanwhile like. Fucking Dr. Dre gets everything he fuckin wants. People are by and large quiet about his horrid fuckin behavior. They invite him onstage to pretend unity with him against Drake is some kind of win.

But everybodys fixated on calling women mean, cant focus on that other behavior. I dont even like participating in those convos when theyre true bc it feels like a damn tar pit

author: @rooboatdeer22yu51
text: I know that we never really know anything about celebrities, but intuition is a very powerful thing. And you don't need to tap into your intuition to see that Ice spice the deals with self hatred. You just have to have a basic understanding of psychology. Hurt people hurt people, it's not an assumption that was made from no evidence. The rebuttal she has given and the behaviors she has exhibited is not the behavior of someone who loves themselves or cares about love. I'm not trying to drag the creator who said it's an assumption to say that she has self hatred. Psychology is not everybody's thing and not everybody can see the deeper mechanisms of other people's behavior. We all have areas of our intuition that are stronger than others, mean behavior and self-love do not coexist. As human beings we will always have an edge about us, there will always be some sort of imperfection. But consistently self-love and being terrible to people does not coexist. If you expect your friend to portray you as something you are not, big sign of self-hatred. If you try to torture your friend over some small situation, big sign of self-hatred. If you care about money more than integrity big sign of self hatred. I used to be the type of person who would say we don't know if someone is in pain or not or if someone is self-hating or not, but after studying human behavior for a long while and having a passion for it, everyone has trauma and levels of self-hatred that they're working through. And it would be naive of me, to think that mean nasty people do not have a level of self-hatred happening. Why would she steal her friends style if she liked herself? She's allowed to be defensive, she's in an impossible situation. Many decisions she made do not display self-love. I was taught from my family that people are allowed to have whatever beliefs they want. I agree somewhat, I don't think beliefs should be forced upon people, that is not loving at all. But it's strange to say that some beliefs aren't negative and don't have a negative impact. If you display negativity to people outside of you, that is mirrored within. The meanness started within, it has an origin. People are kind of afraid to call out what they feel with their intuition, probably because they don't want to offend anybody or they feel like they don't have the authority to say what everybody is picking up on. It's okay to accept that mean people aren't happy. That mean people have not mastered self-love, it's not an assumption. We have evidence as human beings for this, and if you don't know what I'm talking about go look. Go spend time with it Go think about it. You just have to have a logical understanding not even tapped into the creative side of the brain to see it's impossible for a mean person to be mean if it didn't start from the core of the person. I cannot wait until the mainstream knows how important it is for your parents to instill in you self-love, and how important it is for them to teach you emotional intelligence because if you don't have that, your ability to feel joy is severely impacted

author: @zashacandelo1857
text: I always love these conversations. Small thing, I'm from a black latino family and we do just call ourselves black. My grandmother was a black woman descendant directly from slavery the same way a lot of black people in the US are. A lot of us are mixed these days cuz who really gives a shit about dating within your race but those of us who retained their melanin do just call themselves black. We're obviously not Nigerian lol but black latino's are super common, you really don't have to lie about being Nigerian when we've got more than enough culture of our own

author: @virginiawatts4B
text: 10:21 so true I have been confused for Dominican before but the moment I  said I'm mixed but black they were like "oh yeah she is NOT Dominican". It took me years to understand why they accepted my answer so quickly because our skin and hair looked the same. Me claiming blackness was all it took to convince them I was telling the truth.For a second they were confused as to why I only spoke English and was pretending. I had moved to town the same time the town hosted Dominican immigrant families. I really did just look like a liar

author: @SkylarTheWriter
text: I don't think Cleotrapa entered into the friendship with Ice Spice for it to be transactional (but I think Ice Spice definitely did). I think it was genuine for Cleo. The way her voice cracked and she was nearly in tears at one point in the video... Nah, that relationship for Cleo was real. And it was super early in Ice's career. BUT, this whole hurtful drama has proven better for Cleo overall in terms of her rap career. I went and listened to Cleo's discography and she's actually a much better rapper than Ice. She seems to take her craft far more seriously.

author: @eauxkei702
text: The discourse around her father is ridiculous. Her father isn't Latino. Both she and her father have said several times that he is black American. He probably has some Nigerian in him from the ancestry test, so they were doing too much with that, but they have both blatantly said multiple times that her father is NOT Latino in any sense of the word. I don't even like Ice Spice but people are being foolish about that.

author: @sirvirgo1705
text: No shade, but if you make music, it has to be catchy from a music theory perspective. Saying its a talent to make catchy music is like saying its a talent to swim. Its true, but when we are talking about fish, it's the BARE minimum. Ice spice being a sort of musician means, at minimum, her songs have to have replay value aka be catchy. They are as well in a McDonalds kind of way. There are better options, but you're lazy and dont wanna do the work, so you take what you can get, which, musically, would be ice spice

replies.author: @olurinatti
replies.text: Lots of people who make music or are musically talented in some way don‚Äôt make catchy music. In fact, many if not most people who are musically talented still struggle to make hits or catchy music so I don‚Äôt know how you come to the conclusion it‚Äôs the bare minimum requisite and thus, should be dismissed when considering whether someone is talented.

replies.author: @sirvirgo1705
replies.text: @olurinatti¬†  Thank you for responding! talent is kinda subjective, tho. We all see taylor swift as talentless, yet she is heavily praised from a financial and critical standpoint. Count her Granmy's. The point I was trying to make is that when you pick this specific path of music, you HAVE to make catchy music, or else it won't work. As you pointed out, a lot of musicians struggle to make hits, but not every musician is trying to be a star, making music to go on the radio. Ice spice, picking this path of music while having the ability to ride a beat, does not make her talented. Especially with her lyrcism, it's not a good display of talent at all. Also, where would she be if we actually kept a high standard to music? Back in the day, a lot of her music would not lead to a record deal yet alone be considered good. The standard has lowered, and so has our opinion, which is why ice spice can thrive in this musical climate.

text: As a white person, I have no place to state anything in regards to the colorism issues experienced here. From a purely logical standpoint though: although I appreciate Olay's reference to Jouelzy's ASeales analysis about not taking issues online, Cleotrapa did address these issues directly with Ice Spice and her team with no remedy before revealing online what happened.

author: @haroldmoore1206
text: I agree with the point that this feels a little like a pile-on. Not everyone comes up with a radical analysis and framework from which to see the world AND while shabby as hell to do to someone you claim as a friend everything Cleotrapa went through sounds like what most up and coming rappers came through back in the carrying crates tradition of hiphop where artists would have to thug it out for a year or two for no money until their moment came. It's an industry built on luck and hookups and relationships and doesn't have HR or operations like a traditional workplace might. Yes, ice spice should've either handled the business better or the friendship better because the blend is what makes this salacious but Cleo could've helped herself as well. Also the stuff with the other girl feels like a betrayal. Like I can't vent in text messages with my friend? Not everything is a press release, sometimes I'm sharing thoughts that might be ugly or incomplete or relevant in that exact moment. The idea I gotta be saying the right thing all the time might be a reason people go crazy.
